titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Paul Harold Lavietes Papers

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday January 10, 2019 at 10:54

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The papers consist of correspondence, writings, and research material relating to the professional career of Paul H. Lavietes. The papers include items relating to his investigation for possible Communist sympathies by the Veterans Administration and the House Committee on Un-American Activities and document his involvement in medical research, various controversies over drug treatments for diabetes, conflict of interest in the pharmaceutical industry, and the John Punnett Peters Memorial Lectures.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright status for collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Paul Harold Lavietes Papers (MS 1589). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Paul Harold Lavietes was born in New Haven, Connecticut in 1907. He received his B.S. degree from the Sheffield Scientific School, Yale University in 1927 and his M.D. from the Yale School of Medicine in 1930. Lavietes was a physician on the staff of the Yale School of Medicine from 1932 until his retirement in 1987. He also served as a consulting physician at several Connecticut hospitals, including the Veterans Administration Medical Center in West Haven. He was investigated for possible Communist sympathies by the Veterans Administration and the Committee on Un-American Activities during the McCarthy era, and acquitted of all charges after an administrative hearing by the Veterans Administration. Lavietes was a founding editor of the Yale-sponsored Medical Letter on Drugs and Therapeutics and a long-time member of its advisory board. In 1971 he became the founding medical director of the Community Health Care Plan in New Haven, a post from which he retired in 1981. Lavietes specialized in internal medicine, particularly metabolic diseases. He died in 1990.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of correspondence, writings, and research material relating to the professional career of Paul H. Lavietes. The papers include items relating to his investigation for possible Communist sympathies by the Veterans Administration and the House Committee on Un-American Activities and document his involvement in medical research, various controversies over drug treatments for diabetes, conflict of interest in the pharmaceutical industry, and the John Punnett Peters Memorial Lectures.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The papers are arranged in six series: I. General files, 1943-1987, n.d. II. Loyalty case files, 1956, n.d. III. Research files, 1951-1987, n.d. IV. John Punnett Peters files, 1937-1975. V. Writings, 1939-1973. VI. Photographs, 1937-1955, n.d.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: General files chiefly consist of the professional correspondence of Paul Lavietes from 1943 to 1987, typically with fellow physicians and researchers. There are also memoranda and meeting minutes for the Gaylord Farm Association and the Yale-New Haven Hospital Pharmacy and Therapeutics Committee. The files are arranged alphabetically.

did.unittitle: Gaylord Farm Association [meeting minutes and correspondence]
Keating, F. R. [correspondence and background information on thyroxine]
Medical Letter [letter from Paul Lavietes resigning from board of the journal due to Alzheimer's disease]
Yale-New Haven Hospital Pharmacy and Therapeutics Committee [meetings minutes and background material]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The loyalty case files, arranged alphabetically by type of material, concern the 1956 investigation of Paul Lavietes for suspected Communist sympathies by the Veterans Administration and the Committee on Un-American Activities. These files include legal documents and correspondence, lawyers' briefs, affidavits in support of Lavietes's character, transcripts ofofficial testimonies, and related personal correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of research files from Paul Lavietes's years as a physician and as a critic of the pharmaceutical industry and its influence over the medical profession. The files are arranged alphabetically in five sections: Bendectin studies, Pharmaceutical industry, Reference notes, University Group Diabetes Program, and Other. The bulk of the material pertains to the controversy over the anti-nausea drug Bendectin as a possible cause of birth defects, to Lavietes's battles with the pharmaceutical industry, and to the University Group Diabetes Program's research on diabetes treatments. Other items in the series include Lavietes's notes on reference sources and his research files for other medical interests, including the drug aminoglutethimide.

In the 1960s, Lavietes became an outspoken advocate of federal regulation of the prescription of drugs, especially those affecting diabetes and other metabolic diseases. He believed that doctors were encouraged to prescribe unnecessary medications as a result of the medical profession's financial support by the pharmaceutical industry, which included advertising in journals like the Medical Tribune , sponsorship of medical research, and financial contributions to medical societies' conferences. In Lavietes's view, only strict federal guidelines could counteract this influence. The files for Bendectin, the pharmaceutical industry, and the University Group Diabetes Program all reflect Lavietes' interest in these issues.

In the early 1980s, the medical and legal trials over the anti-nausea drug Bendectin and the birth defects it had caused attracted Lavietes's attention. The Bendectin studies material is comprised of his correspondence, news clippings, research notes, and other background materials, as well as the trial deposition of Isalene Apperson Smock, a medical secretary who helped Bendectin's manufacturers gather clinical information about its possible dangers.

The pharmaceutical industry files contain information on drug company sponsorship of medical conferences, and drafts and background information for Lavietes's 1966 speech to the American Society of Internal Medicine on the influence of drug companies on the medical profession. There is also material pertaining to the 1971 expulsion of Dr. Louis Lasagna from the Advisory Board of The Medical Letter . Lasagna was accused of having a conflict-of-interest in his opposition to the removal of the drug Panalba from the market, stemming from his connections to the drug's manufacturer, Upjohn.

The University Group Diabetes Program (UGDP), a consortium of university medical centers, including Yale, sponsored multi-year and multi-clinical trials ofdifferent diabetes treatments in the late 1960s and the 1970s. When the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) labeled particular hypoglycemic agents according to UGDP findings, the CIBA-GEIGY Corporation stridently protested in both FDA hearings and the federal courts. By 1975, drug companies had begun a major media campaign against the UGDP's conclusions and convinced the FDA to audit the UGDP's research protocols and practices. The files include medical studies, legal material, correspondence, and other items relating to the controversy over oral hypoglycemic agents and the UGDP, and to Lavietes' role in that controversy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The fourth series includes Paul Lavietes's files on his mentor John Punnett Peters, and is arranged by type of material. In addition to a biography of Peters by Lavietes, a bibliography of Peters's publications, and memorial tributes to him following his death, there is correspondence with Lavietes regarding the John Punnett Peters Memorial Lectureship from 1956 to 1975. Additional information of the life and career of Peters can be found in the John Punnett Peters Papers (Manuscript Group 897).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Consists of tatement and documents regarding accusations of Communist sympathies against Peters by the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

did.unittitle: Poems [read on the occasion of John Punnett Peters' fiftieth birthday celebration]
'Endocrine Ballads' [humorous reminiscences of Peters by John Homans]
'John Punnett Peters: An Appreciation'[article by Lavietes; correspondence]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Writings are arranged by type and include published lectures of Paul Lavietes and John Punnett Peters from 1939 and reprints ofarticles by Lavietes from 1964 and 1973.

did.unittitle: "Serum Lipids of Normal Subject with Aging" [reprint]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Photographs series consists of black and white photographs of John Punnett Peters, Paul Lavietes, and the twenty-fifth reunion ofthe Yale School ofMedicine Class of 1930, and is arranged alphabetically.

did.unittitle: Peters, John Punnett and Paul Lavietes
